title: 2024 Recap And What to Expect in 2025
description:
2024 was big, with

- 2 Conferences and 4 retreats
- 50,000+ website visits
- Dozens of new articles
- 100+ CFI mentorship applications
- 100s 1-on-1s

But 2025 will be even bigger! 

JD reflects on the year and what's to come, plus challenges you to share about effective giving this Christmas season.

Merry Christmas from JD, Dominic, Alex, Vesa, Asia and the rest of the team

title: What is impact? Christians for Impact at Impact Careers Mixer in London
First-timers at an EACH Conference - 2024 EACH Conference
description:
Welcome to the 2024 EACH Conference! Here is how you can make the most out of this conference and our community. 

Speaker: Asia Wiaterek 

2024 EACH Conference
https://www.eaforchristians.org/each-2024-conference

title: Courage, Christianity, and the AI Revolution - 2024 EACH Conference
description:
Emily is an AI Policy & Public Communications Advisor. In this talk, she gives insights into the recent progress in AI and walks us through her career journey to AI policy. She also discusses why she hopes many Christians are called to this cause area.

Speaker: Emily Dardaman 

2024 EACH Conference 
https://www.eaforchristians.org/each-2024-conference

title: Closing Talk - 2024 EACH Conference
description:
Take the Giving What We Can pledge: https://www.givingwhatwecan.org/pledge/flow?c=header 

Free Christian career mentorship by Christians for Impact: https://www.christiansforimpact.org/get-1-on-1-advice

Connect with us: https://linktr.ee/effectivealtruismforchristians

title: Can We Do More For The Poor Than They Can For Themselves? - 2024 EACH Conference
description:
"What is an appropriate minimum standard for international development programming?  Cash benchmarking proposes that the ethical answer is to make sure the aid industry adds value to the money entrusted to it.  In other words, "Are we doing more for the poor than they can do for themselves?"

Speaker: Daniel Handel 

2024 EACH Conference
https://www.eaforchristians.org/each-2024-conference

title: Who Knows If We’re Helping? - 2024 EACH Conference
description:
Raising concerns about the ethical use of evidence in the Christian nonprofit space.
Some urgent concerns and a path forward, based on a forthcoming paper by Colin Aitken, JD Bauman and Asia Wiaterek.

Speaker: Colin Aitken 

2024 EACH Conference 
https://www.eaforchristians.org/each-2024-conference

title: Doing The Most Good Per Dollar: Cash Incentives For Vaccinations - 2024 EACH Conference
description:
Nigeria has some of the highest under-five mortality rates and lowest vaccination rates in the world. This session will explore the work of New Incentives, a GiveWell top charity. The talk will also delve into the role that saving lives plays in the Christian narrative and how effective storytelling can amplify the mission of nonprofits.

Speaker: Liz Hixson 

2024 EACH Conference 
https://www.eaforchristians.org/each-2024-conference

title: Optimizing For Impact At The Bible Project - 2024 EACH Conference
description:
This talk is about why you should definitely read the Bible, and why you should maybe work in operations. We’ll discuss why “helping people read the Bible” is an important cause area, what it’s like working in “operations” at a high-impact organization, and how to know if you should take an “operations” job.

Speaker: Ben Thomas

2024 EACH Conference 
https://www.eaforchristians.org/each-2024-conference

title: Faith, tears and impact: Two years of building Vida Plena, a mental health org in Ecuador
description:
Mental health treatment is often considered a luxury, only affordable to citizens of high-income countries. But people everywhere struggle with mental health, including many of the world’s poorest, most disadvantaged. This session explores group talk therapy, a potentially highly effective and scalable mental-health treatment for the poor.

Speaker: Joy Bittner 

2024 EACH Conference
https://www.eaforchristians.org/each-2024-conference

title: Raising the Ambition of the Church - 2024 EACH Conference
description:
The Church should reclaim its role as a major player in the development of new social, scientific, and technological innovations. We will need to raise our level of ambition as we seek to build the Kingdom of God on Earth.

Speaker: Caleb Watney 

2024 EACH / Christians for Impact Conference 
https://www.eaforchristians.org/each-2024-conference

title: Closing Talk - EACH 2024 Conference
description:
Thank you for being part of this year's EACH Conference! We hope you enjoyed it, made connections, and gained a better understanding of some of today's most pressing problems and how we can tackle them as Christians using our time, resources and careers. 

EACH 2024 Washington D.C. Conference
https://www.eaforchristians.org/each-2024-conference

title: Charity Navigator’s New Impact Metrics
description:
Nancy is an Executive Human Resources Professional with over twenty years of experience in the Human Resources field.  She has worked with Employee Engagement, Mentoring, Project Management, Talent Acquisition, and Strategic Planning. 

She has an MBA from Old Dominion University. She worked for 10 years at operation smile and has since transitioned to Charity Navigators, where she is Vice President of HR. 

Find out more about Charity Navigator: https://www.charitynavigator.org/

title: Fireside Chat: Bruce Friedrich (GFI) On Max-Impact Creation Care
description:
A chat with Bruce Friedrich, the founder and CEO of the Good Food Institute, a nonprofit think tank working to make the global food system better for the planet, people, and animals. GFI has more than 150 staff across six affiliates in the United States, India, Israel, Brazil, Asia Pacific, and Europe.

https://www.givedirectly.org/

title: Remembering Our Identity
description:
Seminar #9 at EACH 2023 London Conference
https://www.eaforchristians.org/2023-annual-conference

This session will wrap up themes from the conference, outline next steps, and encourage listeners to remain strong in their faith in Jesus, while engaging with effective altruism. 

Speaker: JD Bauman

Note: The presenter's views aren't necessarily the views of EA for Christians.

title: Can Christians Prevent the Next Pandemic?
description:
How bad could a future pandemic be? How might gain-of-function research and DNA sequencing technology be used to “play God” and engineer globally catastrophic diseases? Plus, next steps for Christian careers in biosecurity.

Seminar #8 at EACH 2023 London Conference
https://www.eaforchristians.org/2023-annual-conference

Speaker: Dr. Ana Karina Pitol

Slido: https://app.sli.do/event/gD42KK6cpESmS8hZ33GBCi

Note: The presenter's views aren't necessarily the views of EA for Christians.

title: Get The Most Out of Climate Action
description:
Should we be hopeful or desperate about climate change? How can a Christian and EA approach boost our search for the most effective steps to take? Is climate change a higher priority than, say, current global poverty? And: can climate action do double duty by serving as a practice ground for further upcoming global risks?

Seminar #7 at EACH 2023 London Conference
https://www.eaforchristians.org/2023-annual-conference

Speaker: Dr. Dominic Roser

FP Climate Change Fund -- www.founderspledge.com/funds/climate-change-fund

Climate Change full report - www.givingwhatwecan.org/cause-areas/long-term-future/climate-change/full-report

Unfashionable Climate Interventions - www.80000hours.org/podcast/episodes/johannes-ackva-unfashionable-climate-interventions

Note: The presenter's views aren't necessarily the views of EA for Christians.

title: A Flourishing Life: Scaling evidence-based depression treatment for the vulnerable
description:
Mental health treatment is often considered a luxury, only affordable to citizens of high-income countries. But people everywhere struggle with mental health, including many of the world’s poorest, most disadvantaged. This session explores group talk therapy, a potentially highly effective and scalable mental-health treatment for the poor.

Seminar #6 at EACH 2023 London Conference
https://www.eaforchristians.org/2023-annual-conference

Speaker: Joy Bittner of Vida Plena

Slido: https://app.sli.do/event/2e8k7J9W18jFsgRA16mxBf

title: Measuring What Matters
description:
How might Christians best define impact? Is it the same as wellbeing, virtue, or some other intangible thing? Is “spiritual impact” something that we can measure?

Seminar #5, a fireside chat at EACH 2023 London Conference
https://www.eaforchristians.org/2023-annual-conference

Speakers: Dr. James Waters and Samuel Dupret

Slido: https://app.sli.do/event/2Kai4NB6XnYFFMZMWFWJLA

Note: The presenter's views aren't necessarily the views of EA for Christians.

title: The Power – and Pitfalls – of Impact Measurement
description:
Rigorous impact evaluation is a powerful tool for identifying high-impact organizations. But where does that leave programs that, for a variety of reasons, are challenging to evaluate? This session will explore specific examples of programs that may merit a closer look from EAs and Christians.

Speaker: Kate Sturla

Seminar #3 at EACH 2023 London Conference
https://www.eaforchristians.org/2023-annual-conference

Slido: https://app.sli.do/event/r8FhJYfe6toUHRdj3gKG17 

Note: The presenter's views aren't necessarily the views of EA for Christians, nor the view of her employer.

https://www.eaforchristians.org/2023-annual-conference

title: Daniel Ajudeonu on Effective Altruism in Sub-Saharan Africa
description:
What is Effective Altruism like in Sub-Saharan Africa? Listen to Daniel Ajudeonu and Dominic Roser discuss EA in Nigeria!

Daniel Ajudeonu is pursuing a career in nuclear security. He is Executive Board Member of International Student/Young Pugwash and member of International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons (ICAN).

Originally given at an EACH online speaker event on October 29th 2022

title: How To Give More Effectively Using A DAF (donor-advised fund)
description:
www.charityvest.org

*EA for Christians does not endorse CharityVest.*

Stephen Kump, CEO of Charityvest, shares answers to these questions for US-based Christians and others in the Effective Altruism movement looking to give in the maximally effective ways.

 For one EA-inspired comparison of donor-advised funds see here: https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/qYuehBsAe6Ri6PZvL/a-comparison-of-donor-advised-fund-providers

title: Living in a van to donate 90% to the poor, with Oliver Yeung
description:
What would it be like to donate not just 10% of your money to effective charities, but 90%? How can you afford the rent, especially in higher cost-of-living places, while maintaining such a high level of giving? Short answer - you can't.

But you could live in a van. And that's exactly what Oliver Yeung did when, after graduating college, he landed a job at a top tech firm in California and moved into a mini-van.

Oliver's story isn't just about van life and giving money. It's also about his faith in Jesus and how knowing God and trusting his Word motivated him to give up worldly riches.

Recorded on 5/22/22

title: Robert MacSwain on Sainthood and Effective Altruism
description:
Are effective altruists saints? Effective altruism urges radical generosity and using one's money or career to serve others as much as possible. Some people in the movement give away the majority of their income or make other great sacrifices. But what does sainthood really mean?

Robert MacSwain is an Episcopal priest of the Oratory of the Good Shepherd who teaches theology at the University of the South in Sewanee, Tennessee.

The speaker's views aren't necessarily the views of EACH but are intended for discussion to help Christians in EA make up their own minds.

Originally given at an EA for Christians online speaker event March 9 2022

title: Kidney Donation with Thomas Kelly
description:
Thomas Kelly and Vesa Hautala havea a fireside chat about kidney donation. Should more Christian effective altruists donate one of their kidneys? Is it an effective way to help others or just an attention-getting way? Also, hear why kidney donation may be less attractive to Christian effective altruists than to secular effective altruists. Thomas Kelly is a living kidney donor, co-founder of Waitlist Zero, and a visiting assistant professor of political science at Denison University.

The speaker's views aren't necessarily the views of EACH but are intended for discussion to help Christians in EA make up their own minds.

Originally given at EA for Christians online speaker event February 12th 2022

title: Pandemic preparedness and disease control with Ana Karina Pitol
description:
Are we prepared for the next pandemic? Where are there grave risks in our biosecurity? Ana Karina Pitol is a microbiologist specialized in pathogens and human health and has researched the transmission of schistosomiasis and SARS-CoV-2.

The speaker's views aren't necessarily the views of EACH but are intended for discussion to help Christians in EA make up their own minds.

Q&A
32:40 question #1 could we differentiate leak of sample from gain of function research?
36:48 question #2 Are you more concerned about states or individuals/groups making bioterror agents?
38:39 question #3 Who is doing data work to predict return spillovers of SARS-COV-2?
42:26 question #4 Are there any public charities with room for funding that you think may be highly effective at making progress on this issue?
44:14 question #5 What are your thoughts on the failures of the model of an internal review board versus making that more an external responsibility? The challenge is there is a pressure to approve your colleagues’ work.

Originally given at an EACH online speaker event January 22nd 2022

title: Mike Morell CS Lewis and EA
description:
Mike Morell, a fund manager from New Jersey, shares his personal journey into faith and effective altruism through the works of C.S. Lewis.

Admirers of Lewis will hear how his ideas are being applied today in very practical terms, and learn how to get involved. EAs of all backgrounds will gain insight on how to connect a very modern movement to an old, old story and start a dialogue with anyone in their lives who follows Christ and/or loves Lewis.

The speaker's views aren't necessarily the views of EACH but are intended for discussion to help Christians in EA make up their own minds.

Originally given at an EACH online speaker event on January 8th 2022

www.eaforchristians.org


_________
Brian Green is the director of technology ethics at the Markkula Center for Applied Ethics.

Originally given at an EACH online speaker event on November 13th 2021

title: "Living out Effective Altruism", Jay Dykstra
description:
Jason Dykstra speaks about putting effective altruism into pracice in a fireside chat. Themes of the chat include:
- How to resolve tradeoffs around giving vs. saving?
- What about tithing to my local church?
- What does the Bible say about effectiveness?

The speaker's views aren't necessarily the views of EACH but are intended for discussion to help Christians in EA make up their own minds.

This talk was hosted by EA for Christians.
www.eaforchristians.org

Topic 1: 01:12 Jason's story
Topic 2: 02:24 Church and effective altruism
Topic 3: 08:34 Using our nonfinancial resources for effective altruism
Topic 4: 14:50 Careers: earning to give versus impactful work, advice for people thinking about career questions
Topic 5: 23:33 Is there a simple stepwise process to take all these ideas and make them realistic and simplt to apply in your life?

_________
Jason Dykstra is an experienced medical doctor and practitioner of EA. For over 15 years he has helped young adults customize sustainable plans for fulfilling EA lifestyles.

Originally given at an EACH online speaker event on October 16th 2021

title: Giving What We Can and the Giving Pledge | Pablo Melchor | Effective Altruism for Christians
description:
Pablo Melchor speaks about Giving What We Can and its Giving Pledge, a commitment to donate at least 10% of one's income to effective charity. He also shares his own story. 

The speaker's views aren't necessarily the views of EACH but are intended for discussion to help Christians in EA make up their own minds.

This talk was hosted by EA for Christians.
www.eaforchristians.org

Talk: 1:34 - 31:43
Q&A: 

Question 1: 32:06 How does Giving What We Can split its efforts between giving more and giving more effectively and what do you think is more effective?
Question 2: 33:48 Is there a difference between the Giving What We Can Recommended Charities and the recommendations by GiveWell?
Question 3: 35:03 What does the Giving What We Can community do in practice to help keep its members committed to giving? 
Question 4: 38:17 Does GWWC mainly reach out to the existing EA community or does it also do outreach outside the current community?

_________
Pablo Melchor is a member of Giving What We Can and cofounder and president of the Spanish EA organization Ayuda Efectiva.

Originally given at an EACH online speaker event on October 2nd 2021

title: Introduction to Effective Altruism for Christians
description:
Want to find out more about how you can make an impact with your career and resources? Visit www.eaforchristians.org, and follow us at www.facebook.com/eaforchristians.

Narrated by Juliet Mee (www.workingwiththevoice.com)
Edited by Jonny Rogers (www.youtube.com/user/strontiumblog)
Written by David & Jonny Rogers

// References //

Dhaliwal, I., Dulflo, E., Glennerster, R. & Tulloch, C. ‘Comparative Cost-Effectiveness Analysis to Inform Policy in Developing Countries: A General Framework with Applications for Education’, Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (2012). URL: https://www.povertyactionlab.org/sites/default/files/research-resources/CEA%20in%20Education%202013.01.29_0.pdf

'This is your most important decision: Why your career is your biggest opportunity to make a difference, and how you can use it best’, 80,000 Hours. URL: https://80000hours.org/make-a-difference-with-your-career/

Wesley, J. ‘The Use of Money’, The Sermons of John Wesley (1872). URL: https://johnwesleysermons.com/sermons/the-use-of-money

White, C. E. ‘What Wesley Practiced and Preached About Money’, Christianity Today (1987). URL: https://www.christianitytoday.com/pastors/1987/winter/87l1027.html

‘World Bank Forecasts Global Poverty to Fall Below 10% for First Time; Major Hurdles Remain in Goal to End Poverty by 2030’, The World Bank (2015). URL: https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2015/10/04/world-bank-forecasts-global-poverty-to-fall-below-10-for-first-time-major-hurdles-remain-in-goal-to-end-poverty-by-2030

‘World malaria report 2020: 20 years of global progress and challenges’, World Health Organisation (2020). URL: https://www.who.int/teams/global-malaria-programme/reports/world-malaria-report-2020/

Week 41, August 15th 2021

title: Fireside chat with Jason Dykstra: Making EA work in everyday life | EA for Christians
description:
Jay shares realistic and long-term paths to impact, important considerations at adult milestones, EA-friendly church models, and more, with Grayden Reece-Smith, an advisor for EA for Christians.

The speaker's views aren't necessarily the views of EACH but are intended for discussion to help Christians in EA make up their own minds.

This talk was hosted by EA for Christians. www.eaforchristians.org

Talk: 1:57 - 32:30

Q&A:

Question 1: 32:50​​ How you balance international giving and still caring for your local community?
Question 2: 36:43 What's your methodology in selecting your BlessBig recommended charities? It seems some are more cost-effective than Givewell charities, others less.

________
Jay Dykstra is an experienced medical doctor who is a longtime practitioner of effective altruism. For over 15 years he has helped young adults customize sustainable plans for fulfilling EA lifestyles.

He is the founder of worldwidehousechurch.org, a free global small group and house church network that makes faith communities more flexible and EA-friendly. He also founded blessbig.org, a "Give Well for Christians" that meta-analyzes numerous charity evaluator sites, making EA-based recommendations that include Christian orgs and more diverse cause groups. Jay has been featured on the blog of The Life You Can Save, at the Global Missions Health Conference, and in the Washington Post.

Originally given on April 24 2021 at the EA for Christians 2021 Conference

title: Why should Christians care about farmed animal welfare? | David Clough | EA for Christians
description:
David talks about why Christians should care about animal welfare and how the church can move us towards a world where farmed animals flourish.

The speaker's views aren't necessarily the views of EACH but are intended for discussion to help Christians in EA make up their own minds.

This talk was hosted by EA for Christians. 
www.eaforchristians.org

Talk: 2:25 - 33:10
Q&A:

Question 1: 33:25 How does the fact that Jesus ate fish undermine your view? It seems to suggest that it is sometimes okay to prioritize superficial interest over animal lives.
Question 2: 35:25 Givewell estimates that it's roughly $5,000 to save a life by giving to the Against Malaria Foundation, and Animal Charity Evaluators estimates the same amount frees 10,000+ chickens from cages. How do you resolve such tradeoffs?
Question 3: 37:58 What do you think is a compassionate, yet affordable and healthy diet?

________
David Clough is a professor of theology and leads the Christian Ethics of Farmed animal welfare project at the University of Chester. He has advocated for the better treatment of animals by founding organizations such as CreatureKind and DefaultVeg and is now using his academic position to put animal welfare on the agenda of Churches in the UK. 

Originally given on April 24 2021 at the EA for Christians 2021 Conference

title: Amplifying capital flows to people in extreme poverty | Paul Niehaus | EA for Christians
description:
Paul shares his journey, faith, and innovative work in reducing global poverty through GiveDirectly, Taptap Send, and Segovia.

The speaker's views aren't necessarily the views of EACH but are intended for discussion to help Christians in EA make up their own minds.

This talk was hosted by EA for Christians. Moderated by Evan McVail.
www.eaforchristians.org

Talk: 2:35 - 28:55

Q&A:

Question 1: 28:55 As an economist, do you perceive any tension between, on the one hand, having shorter-run transfers/poverty alleviation, and on the other hand, growth? 
Question 2: 31:23 To what extent do you think Christian effective altruists should try to drive change within existing NGOs such as Samaritans Purpose, Compassion, or Tearfund?
Question 3: 34:15 Why do we never hear pastors and other Christian leaders implore the faithful to focus more on effectiveness and evidence?
Question 4: 38:11  What are three books that you would recommend to the audience that have really influenced you, both in your faith and in your journey to amplify capital flows to people living in extreme poverty?


________
Associate Professor Paul Niehaus is co-founder and chairman of GiveDirectly, a GiveWell top charity. GiveDirectly is a recognized leader in the use of modern technology to transfer funds directly to the extreme poor, and in the use of rigorous scientific methods to document its impact. 

Paul is also a co-founder of Segovia, which builds enterprise technology for the management of social programming in emerging markets.
He holds an academic appointment in the Department of Economics at UC San Diego, holds a PhD in economics from Harvard University and is a National Science Foundation Fellow and a Sloan Fellow. In 2013 Foreign Policy named him one of its 100 leading "Global Thinkers."

Originally given on April 24 2021 at the EA for Christians 2021 Conference

title: Faith, EA, and the Climate Emergency | Dominic Roser | Effective Altruism for Christians
description:
What are the most useful EA contributions to the climate debate? Should Christians be particularly skeptical or enthusiastic?

The speaker's views aren't necessarily the views of EACH but are intended for discussion to help Christians in EA make up their own minds.

This talk was hosted by EA for Christians. Moderated by JD Bauman.
www.eaforchristians.org

Talk: 1:15 - 28:17

Q&A:

Question 1: 28:42 Do you think personal changes, like going zero-waste or electric cars, useful? Or just not effective enough for time and money?
Question 2: 30:13 How can a pro-growth strategy for climate change address the christian aims of justice, meaning, the impacts on the poor and the west's historic emissions?
Question 3: 31:46 What role, if any, can EA play in for-profit innovation in climate change mitigation?
Question 4: 32:23 God asked us to be good stewards and to cultivate and tend for the earth. Why should we pursue growth, which usually means more humans in a worse earth?
________
Dr. Dominic Roser is a senior lecturer at the Interdisciplinary Institute for Ethics and Human Rights of the University of Fribourg in Switzerland. As a philosopher and economist, his work has mainly focused on the ethics of climate change.

Originally given on April 24 2021 at the EA for Christians 2021 Conference

title: How Should Christians Think about Existential Risk? | Brian Green |Effective Altruism for Christians
description:
This talk is about how Christians ought to approach existential risks (e.g. nuclear disaster, catastrophic global pandemics, etc.).
The speaker's views aren't necessarily the views of EACH but are intended for discussion to help Christians in EA make up their own minds.

This talk was hosted by EA for Christians. 
www.eaforchristians.org

Talk: 0:00 - 16:20

Q&A:

Question 1: 16:43 Even if humans have the freedom to sin grievously, should Christians be at least less concerned about existential risk compared to secular effective altruists? Esp. given the biblical end times.
Question 2: 18:30 Dominic Roser argued that longtermism, if stretched too far in time, is presumptuous. Then where is the line? Decades, centuries?
Question 3: 20:51​ Given that only a few people will ever be in the position of launching a nuclear missile, what can the average person do to avoid existential risks?
Question 4: 24:54 Some Christian seem to define near existential risks scenarios as bringing about the second coming. Should we be worried that avoiding existential risks avoids God’s plans?
Question 5: 27:28 Would you agree that Christians have stronger reasons to fight anthropogenic risks than natural ones?
Question 6: 29:44 To what extent has past research on global pandemic risk helped during the covid crisis? Should we just optimize for existential risks at and when they arrive?

________
Dr. Brian Patrick Green is the director of technology ethics at the Markkula Center for Applied Ethics. His work is focused on the ethics of technology, including AI and space exploration. 

He is also a member of the Safety-Critical AI working group at the Partnership on Artificial Intelligence to Benefit People and Society.

Originally given on April 24 2021 at the EA for Christians 2021 Conference
